SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: FBI boss says gun check breakdown allowed Dylann Roof to buy weapon

Charleston gunman Dylann Roof should never have been been able to buy the gun he used to kill nine worshippers at a church Bible study last month, the FBI director said Friday, citing a breakdown in the national background check system.
A loophole allowed the 21-year-old to buy the .45-caliber handgun with money given to him for his birthday despite a criminal record that included a recent drug possession charge, James Comey said.
Wow just Wow and a Felon.

FBI couldn't make a final determination in the 3-days allowed so the dealer was allowed to release it. people are saying that that mean that the 3-day rule needs to be extended (even indefinitely if need be) but those people don't realize that if there isn't a hard deadline then an anti-gun President could EO the FBI to slow-play all BG checks so that all gun purchases took months or years to complete. that 3-day rule is there specifically to stop that.
so after the 3 day and the FBI figured he should not have the weapon should the FFL and local police have been notified to recover the weapon?

Dylan roof was just stupid enough to get stopped by a cop and consent to a search to get himself arrested. Had he a single brain cell, he could easily have never been arrested. The trespassing arrest wasn't a felony, iirc. Even if it was, again not any indication that he's about to go postal.

I could see if he was arrested for felony assault with a deadly weapon or making threats. Then it would be like, yeah we really missed the boat on this one. If anything, I blame the friends more for knowing he had a gun and making threats to kill random people. Even then though, who really knew?
I understand the technicality of it(he shouldn't have passed the background) but I guess I'm looking at the bigger picture.

No, according to the law, if he was under indictment for a prohibiting crime, he was disqualified from purchasing a firearm. It's right on the 4473. NICS was supposed to have captured the prohibiting arrest, but you know how that goes.

Dylan roof was just stupid enough to get stopped by a cop and consent to a search to get himself arrested. Had he a single brain cell, he could easily have never been arrested. The trespassing arrest wasn't a felony, iirc. Even if it was, again not any indication that he's about to go postal.

Doesn't matter. He was an unlawful user of a controlled substance, and that is a specific question (11e) on the 4473. Furthermore, 11b asks if you are currently under indictment for a felony, which he may have been. I'm not sure if possession is a wobbler in SC, but FBI jacked this up pretty bad. Now the question is what will come of it? Changing policy so that a green light MUST be given before a firearm is released? I'm thinking that's the concession that will be made. Then again, that could mean removal of waiting periods.
I think it's clear- it was the insane bastards fault.
Try him- if convicted, hang him.

The question that remains unanswered is how long did they make him wait before clearing the purchase. They have made much reference to the 72 hours they had, but I have not heard them say how much of that 72 hours they used.

If he was cleared within hours, expect that news to be buried for as long as possible. You can bet your last dollar if they can milk this for a modification to the 72 hour max wait, they will no matter if they cleared him in three hours and they will suppress that as long as they can.

im more of the type who has a strong belief that every now and then the system will make a mistake, you don't get 100% odds on anything realistically...you have the FBI/DOJ relying on information they receive from the courts, you have the clerks of those courts inputting information based on paperwork handed down to them...WHAT CAN GO WRONG? <img src="http://www.calguns.net/calgunforum/images/smilies/smile.gif" border="0" alt="" title="Smile" class="inlineimg">

based on the information in this article its hard to determine what stage Roof was even at in the Judicial process from his arrest...it doesn't say he was convicted, it only says he "admitted" to the drug possession...im guessing he had not been sentenced yet, therefore i doubt there was any kind of conviction for the courts to even record, making his status even more uncertain

creating more restrictions and red tape won't solve the human error factor that is involved with the background process...you'll never achieve 100% results, that's not logical, nor, is there any proof that, had he been denied, this tragedy would have been prevented, only that he would've have to secure a firearm in another fashion, and, we all know that isn't really that difficult for a person set on finding one

that, and the fact that a clean background doesn't mean a person won't go off a cliff mentally at some point, just snap, and, do the same thing...all a clean background does is say "as of <b>today<b>, you're gtg"...that's it

The issue was that the investigator couldn't find the police report because the arresting agency wasn't listed in whatever document they use that lists agencies by county. We don't need new laws; we just need to effectively enforce the ones we have on the books. This wasn't effective enforcement.

If we get locked into the blaming mindset, we're playing into the anti gunners logic. It's along the mindset of, "he used a gun, we need to ban guns." Taking one step away from that and saying, "The government didn't update his background and therefore 9 people are dead" is the same type of thinking.

It's like seeing a fatal traffic accident and declaring that the driver is dead because the airbag didn't save his life but the fact that he was blind drunk and drove 100mph into a tree is completely ignored.

It is out of pure luck that Dylann Roof was a prohibited person. He won the lottery on this one. On any other day the manager of the store he was creeping out at could have just told him to leave and not called the cops. The cop who stopped and questioned him could have been satisfied that he was asking those questions because he really was thinking about applying for a job. The cop also could have not bothered fishing and getting Dylann to consent to a search. Dylann also could have never decided to go to the mall that day, either. He also could have remembered to take the suboxone strips out of his pants before leaving his car. Then where would we be? Just another off the radar nut shooter.

Even his felony drug charge probably would have gotten plead down. This kid had two arrests, the drug felony and trespassing at the same mall a month or two later. It's not like he was dealing and caught with 5lbs of heroin. He probably would have gotten rehab and community service and the felony nixed, most likely.

Can we, <b>THROUGH EXISTING LAW<b>, improve reporting for bg checks? Sure. Let's not make it the sole reason why this kid killed people,however. Even if this kid was denied getting a gun legally I doubt that would have stopped him. Delayed, probably.
He could have just bought one off Craigslist.
Private firearms transfers (i.e., transfers by non-firearms dealers) are not subject to a background check requirement in South Carolina.
